s.text: RTS with the assistance of all the co-authors developed the digital drusen measurement method and wrote the paper.

Since diabetic exudates tend to be smaller than soft drusen, it is unclear if sufficient featureless windows would be available in an image with multiple soft drusen to apply this method.

Rapantzikos [ 18 ] et al have used other morphological operators as well as varying local histogram criteria for threshold choice to try to correct these deficiencies.
There is still intrinsic variability in terms of the true reflectance of drusen, but the variability in background reflectance is largely eliminated.
All authors read and approved the final manuscript.

Indeed, one reason we are presenting our particular method is that we found after many trials and errors that none of the standard morphological transform routines (dilations, erosion, closings) or combinations thereof, were able to precisely define the boundary of pathological features in a fundus image.
This means that if it is important to have the greatest precision in a particular subregion other than the standard subfields, a specific threshold for this region should be chosen separately.

At the present level of automation, this method can give drusen measurements at a higher level of precision (+/- 5%) than the widely used International Classification System, with a tradeoff of longer operator time until background leveling can be fully automated.

Since we were dealing with photography, not photometry, the choice of multiplicative or additive correction attempted to preserve semi-quantitative relationships of reflectance rather than absolute levels or precise numerical relationships [ 31 ] . Further, since reflectance variability was at issue, rather than absolute levels, we considered only the most variable components: the macular luteal pigment, dealt with above, the nerve fiber layer [ 32 33 34 35 ] , and the RPE melanin [ 36 ] . The RPE melanin is denser in the fovea, and as such will reduce the reflectance of underlying drusen in much the same manner as the luteal pigment.
The measurements were often closer for those images with scanty drusen (<10%) in which Grader 2 made estimates to within 1%, but these findings were not statistically significant.
The images were saved as 24-bit RGB TIFF files, with 256 levels of intensity value for each color channel.
Image Processing

Another application of this method to a drusen image is seen in Fig 4. The first frame is the standardized color image, which then was contrast-enhanced in Photoshop for ease of drusen visualization (middle frame).

On review, intra-observer disagreements appeared to be more due to the subjective choice of threshold for final segmentation rather than to disparities in the final background-leveled image to which the threshold was applied.
Likewise, variation in the placement of the ovals in the interactive steps would lead to local irregular variability in the final leveled image.
The first step in the semi-automated method was therefore to apply the above correction to the green channel of the standardized image if luteal pigment was present.
TN contributed image analysis and software expertise in method development.
For uniformity of processing, all images were resized with bicubic interpolation so that the distance from the center of the macula to the temporal disc edge was 490 pixels.

Lastly, despite the use of a wide range of general image analysis tools, their methods, as those in the other references, take no account of the intrinsic background variability, and accordingly can produce errors in a systematic and predictable fashion: inadequate segmentation centrally and over inclusive segmentation in the peripheral macula, as their own illustrations demonstrate.
The resulting standardized images had the property that relative variation in brightness on a small scale was preserved with respect to the originals.

We found that percentage increases in gray scale value of 3.5, 2.5, 1.5 and 1.0 percent, applied over the inner disc and three outer annuli of diameters 375, 700, 1000 and 1250 ?m, respectively, provided essentially complete pattern corrections for some images, partial corrections for some images, but overcorrections (pattern reversal) in none.
TN contributed image analysis and software expertise in method development.

Indeed, one reason we are presenting our particular method is that we found after many trials and errors that none of the standard morphological transform routines (dilations, erosion, closings) or combinations thereof, were able to precisely define the boundary of pathological features in a fundus image.

We found that percentage increases in gray scale value of 3.5, 2.5, 1.5 and 1.0 percent, applied over the inner disc and three outer annuli of diameters 375, 700, 1000 and 1250 ?m, respectively, provided essentially complete pattern corrections for some images, partial corrections for some images, but overcorrections (pattern reversal) in none.
For uniformity of processing, all images were resized with bicubic interpolation so that the distance from the center of the macula to the temporal disc edge was 490 pixels.
Testing of the digital method showed good inter-observer reproducibility in two independent measurements of 24 subfields (two subfields each from 12 images).

However, we had found that the macular reflectance patterns in standardized images from normal subjects from other races were the same as those of Caucasians [ 26 ] . Hence no new difficulty would be anticipated in drusen segmentation in these populations.
Drusen area in each of the 12 digital images was measured in both the central and middle subfields by two independent graders (RTS and JKC) using the semi-automated method.
TN contributed image analysis and software expertise in method development.
For uniformity of processing, all images were resized with bicubic interpolation so that the distance from the center of the macula to the temporal disc edge was 490 pixels.
While the offsets are mathematically arbitrary, and do not affect a study of image variation numerically, we found that human recognition of fundus features was essential.

As proof of principle, we first demonstrated that the interactive procedure was effective in eliminating the concentric shading pattern in both a normal image (Figure 2A,2B,2C,2D) and a drusen-containing image (Figure 2E,2F,2G,2H).
For a given threshold, the drusen image is segmented such that pixels with brightness intensities above the threshold are colored green, to label as drusen, and the rest darkened.

The resulting correction in any cross-section through the center was thus a series of step functions, which roughly approximated a Gaussian distribution A smoother approximation could have been achieved outside Photoshop, but the visual results of the current scheme were smooth to human observation.
The mean gray scale values of these regions are then used to determine local thresholds, which are then interpolated to give a global threshold function.
The option to scale these percentages up or down in a given image was still available, but we chose not to exercise this option in the present study.

The fundamental fact remains, as they readily admit, no matter how many histogram-based criteria are employed for local segmentation, that widely different combinations of image features (drusen and background) can yield the same histogram.
That is, if a dark region of pixels were missed by one oval for brightening, they would still be "too dark" in the next iteration and should be picked up there.

The fundamental fact remains, as they readily admit, no matter how many histogram-based criteria are employed for local segmentation, that widely different combinations of image features (drusen and background) can yield the same histogram.

Color fundus photographs have been routinely employed for diagnostic purposes for many years, and fundus photo gradings are central to clinical studies of macular disease [ 1 2 ] . The natural history of age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the leading cause of blindness in the developed world [ 3 ] , is in particular tied to that of subretinal deposits known as drusen [ 4 5 6 7 8 9 10 11 12 ] . Drusen are key in the classification of AMD, hence the importance of drusen identification and measurement in clinical studies.

Another application of this method to a drusen image is seen in Fig 4. The first frame is the standardized color image, which then was contrast-enhanced in Photoshop for ease of drusen visualization (middle frame).

The drusen images consisted of stereo pairs of standard 35-degree film-based color fundus photographs centered on the macular regions.
